Both Bush and Kerry are putting up some negative TV adds about each other, and sometimes they have "positive" adds about themselves. One of Bush's positive ones is thought provoking to me.
 
 I don't remember every word of the add, but it shows a restauant's lights being turned on, then changes to an average looking two story house. It ends with Bush saying, "If you own something, you have a stake in America". He's talking largely about owning a home or business, but it doesn't have to be on that big a scale. Home owners and business owners aren't the only ones capable of owning something, and not all ownership is about selfish pleasure. Owning some kind of useful tool that not only you, but your neighbors can use - (a big mower, a snowplow, a wood or metal working tool in your basement) a boat bigger than you need, or a racecar, so you can invite friends to go along with you - the list is endless, it's what America is all about, and is good for the economy. I'm not saying there is automatically something wrong with living in an apartment, leasing a car, and working for a big company, many people do it. They choose to spend their money traveling, or countless other things that don't involve ownership, and that's fine. But the question is, do they appreciate private property rights as much as people who do own things?

 50,000 former residents from mostly Oahu, Hawaii have relocated here, Las Vegas, with many more into CA. While the Mainland US has always been a good market for Hawaii's primary industry of tourism, Japan has always been the big gun. When the Japanese economy went soft, so did Hawaii's share of their vacationers. That may again change as the dollar keeps falling against the yen and makes Hawaii a bargain for those spending yen or euros, but it won't help Hawaiian paychecks. An even larger issue facing our travel industry is US paranoia regarding retaliation to our foreign policies. Our efforts at internal security are making us mirror police state attitudes at a time when we're far from being the most popular kid on the block. Asians have many other Pacific paradise vacation locations to choose from and many are saying travel to and in the US just isn't worth it. Keep that future in mind when considering relocation to and purchasing property in Hawaii. 
 
 You're in the same financial position as many young couples raising families, bigger paychecks in metropolitian areas accompanied by what seems like unrealistic housing costs. Relocation outside of rapid growth areas provides realistic housing costs, complete with a substantial drop in income.
